facts.text: School started at Burhanpur by certain members of the Daudi Bohra Community in 1902 named Madrasai Faize Hakimia for religious and secular education to boys of the community.

anchor.surface_text: The school was started at Burhanpur by certain members of the Daudi Bohra Community of Burhanpur in the year 1902. It was named Madrasai Faize Hakimia and its object was to impart religious and secular education to boys of the Daudi Bohra Community.

facts.text: Funds collected from members of Daudi Bohra Community for maintenance of the school.

anchor.surface_text: Funds were collected for the purpose of the school from the members of that community for the maintenance of the school.

facts.text: English classes added to the school in 1908.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1908 English classes were added to the school and in 1911 it was raised to the status of a High School

facts.text: School raised to High School status in 1911 named Madrasai Hakimia and Coronation High School.

anchor.surface_text: and in 1911 it was raised to the status of a High School under the name Madrasai Hakimia and Coronation High School.

facts.text: On May 24, 1909, Abdul Hussain-Abdullali Faizullabhai Muchhala made waqf of properties in Bombay for benefit of school at Burhanpur, appointing 12 existing school trustees.

anchor.surface_text: Some time before this on May 24, 1909 one Daudi Bohra of Surat of the name of Abdul Hussain- Abdullali Faizullabhai Muchhala made a was of certain properties in Bombay for the benefit and advantage of this school at Burhanpur.

facts.text: On September 15, 1909, six Daudi Bohras of Burhanpur executed deed creating waqf and trust of their properties for school, naming 80 trustees including themselves, vesting all school properties in trustees, with powers to manage, frame rules, appoint new trustees.

anchor.surface_text: Only a few months after this another trust came into existence for the benefit of the same school, by a deed executed by six persons, all Daudi Bohras and all belonging to Burhanpur describing themselves as managers of the school.

facts.text: Trustees managed school and properties including 1909 waqf properties without trouble till March 1917, converting some with additional donations.

anchor.surface_text: These trustees managed the school and also the properties belonging, to the school including the properties of which waqf was made in its favour by the trust deed of September 15, 1909 without any trouble till March 1917.

facts.text: Trouble started in 1917 when some community members declared Mullaji Taher Saifuddin Saheb not the Dai-ul-Mutalaq.

anchor.surface_text: Trouble started in 1917 when some members of the Community started declaring that Mullaji Taher Saifuddin Saheb who, according to the main body of the Community was the Dai-ul-Mutalaq was number a Dai-ul-Mutalaq.

facts.text: In March 1917, four out of 18 trustees appointed by 1909 deed plus three others formed Madrasai Hakimia Coronation Society to run the schools, with 12-person governing body, properties vesting in it.

anchor.surface_text: About the same time four out of the 18 who were appointed by the trust deed of September 15, 1909 joined three other members of the Daudi Bohra Community of Burhanpur to form a society by the name of Madrasai Hakimia Coronation Society

facts.text: Defendants 2 to 11 are members of the governing body of the Society.

anchor.surface_text: The 10 persons who have been impleaded as defendants 2 to 11 ,ire members of the governing, body of the Society.

facts.text: Society members administered properties from 1909 trust deed since assuming management.

anchor.surface_text: From the time they assumed the management of the Madrasai Hakimia Coronation High School as members of the Society they have been administering the properties

facts.text: Suit filed under s.92 CPC by 4 Daudi Bohra muslims interested in trust properties listed in Schedule M.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which these appeals have arisen was started under s.92 of the Code of Civil Procedure by 4 Daudi Bohra muslims who claimed to be interested in the trust properties

facts.text: Plaintiffs contended defendants 1 (Hakimia Society) and 2-11 not validly appointed trustees of trust properties.

anchor.surface_text: Their main contention in the plaint is that the first defendant, the Hakimia Society and the 10 defendants, defendants Nos. 2 to 11 were number validly appointed trustees

facts.text: Plaintiffs prayed for declaration defendants not valid trustees, removal, accounts, appointment of new trustees per 1909 deed, scheme if necessary.

anchor.surface_text: They prayed in this suit for a declaration that these defendants are number vaildly appointed trustees for their removal from the management of these properties and for an order on them to render accounts

facts.text: Ground: not appointed per 1909 deed terms; society entrustment invalid; breaches including admitting non-Bohra students.

anchor.surface_text: The ground on which the plaint claimed that these defendants were number validly appointed trustees was that they had number been appointed as such in accordance with the terms and conditions of the trust deed of September 15, 1909.

facts.text: Defendants 12-17 are trustees of Muchhala trust, no relief sought against them.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees of the trust created by Mr. Muchhala were impleaded as defendants 12 to r7. No relief was however asked for against defendants 12 to 17.

facts.text: Defendants 1-11 defended: validly appointed per 1909 rules, properties vested, no breaches.

anchor.surface_text: The main defences of defendants 1 to 11 were that they had been validly appointed trustees of the properties mentioned in the plaint under the trust deed. of September 1909

facts.text: Trial Court held defendants 2-11 validly appointed trustees except Muchhala properties, based on para 6 power to frame rules, register society.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court answered this question in the affirmative. Relying on the provisions of Para. 6 of the trust deed  of September 1909  for the framing of rules and regulations for management of the school and properties connected with the school

facts.text: Trial Court found use of trust funds for 1925 CS No.32 litigation not for school benefit but not misappropriation.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court answered questions 6  a  and  e  in the negative i.e., it found that the governing body did use trust properties or income therefrom for fighting out litigation in C. S. No. 32 of 1925

facts.text: Trial Court refused removal of def 1-11, removed def 12-17, ordered deposits including Rs.15,596-5-8 by def 2-11.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court refused to make a declaration that defendants 1 to 11 were number validly appointed or for their removal. It however gave a decree for the removal of defendants 12 to 72 to 17

facts.text: Plaintiffs appealed to Nagpur High Court; def 12-17 appealed; cross-objections by some def.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree of the Trial Court the plaintiffs preferred an appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur. Another appeal was preferred by defendants 12 to 17

facts.text: Nagpur High Court (now MP) on Oct 30, 1956 dismissed appeals and cross-objections, affirmed trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 30, 1956, of the former Nagpur High Court  Now Madhya Pradesh in F. A. Nos. 79 and 95 of 1949.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals: CA 406/60 by def 12,14-17; CA 407/60 by plaintiffs, by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 466 and 407 of 1960. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 30, 1956

facts.text: SC held no relief sought against def 12-17, allowed CA 406/60.

anchor.surface_text: Their contention is that the Trial Court as also the High Court erred in granting a decree against them when the plaintiffs in the suit had number asked for any such relief.

facts.text: SC held original trustees had no power to divest properties to society/governing body; def 1-11 not valid trustees, to be removed, render accounts.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this contention must succeed. There cannot, in our opinion, be any doubt about the correctness of the legal position that trustees cannot transfer their duties

facts.text: Clause 5 of 1909 deed does not authorize abdication or substitution of trustees.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied therefore that cl.5 of the trust deed does number in any manner authorise the trustees appointed by deed to abdicat in favour of anthor body of persons

facts.text: Def 2-11 paid Rs.15,596-5-8 as ordered.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the amount of Rs. 15,000/-and odd has been already paid by defendants 2 to 11 under the decree of the Trial Courts.

facts.text: SC directs Trial Court to appoint new trustees after hearing recommendations from plaintiffs and community members.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore direct that suitable persons be appointed by the Trial Court as new trustees after giving an opportunity to the plaintiffs and other responsible members

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 17, 1962 by DAS GUPTA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. August 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: Of original 18 trustees, all except one dead, survivor too old.

anchor.surface_text: of the original 18 trustees all except one are dead and sole survivor is admittedly too old to carry on the administration successfully.
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 30, 1956, of the former Nagpur High Court  Now Madhya Pradesh in F. A. Nos. 79 and 95 of 1949.
by special leave granted by this Court. The appeal by defendants 12, and 14 to 17 can be easily disposed of.

issues.text: Whether the original trustees of the Burhanpur trust had power in law to divest themselves of the property vested in them by the trust deed or to vest these properties in any society or its governing body?

holdings.text: The Trial Court and High Court erred in granting a decree for removal and other reliefs against defendants 12 to 17 as no relief was prayed against them in the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Their contention is that the Trial Court as also the High Court erred in granting a decree against them when the plaintiffs in the suit had not asked for any such relief. In our opinion, this contention must be accepted as correct. While it is true that these five appellants,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint read as whole seeks relief only against def 1-11; paras 20,26 refer only to them; no averments against 12-17.

holdings.text: Original trustees of the Burhanpur trust had no power in law to divest themselves of the properties vested in them or to vest them in the society or its governing body.

anchor.surface_text: the first contention raised on their behalf by the learned Solicitor- General is that the original trustees of the Burhanpur trust had no power in law to divest themselves of the property vested in them by the trust deed or to vest these properties in any society or its governing body,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trustees cannot abdicate or delegate entire office without trust deed authority, beneficiary consent, or court permission; general principle against unilateral termination of fiduciary relationship.

holdings.text: Clause 5 of the 1909 trust deed does not authorize the trustees to abdicate in favour of another body or constitute that body as trustees in their place.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied therefore that cl.5 of the trust deed does not in any manner authorise the trustees appointed by deed to abdicate in favour of another body of persons or to constitute that body as trustees in their own place.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: power to frame rules and appoint new trustees means adding to number, not substitution; no provision for divesting properties.

holdings.text: The trust deed of September 1909 covers all movable and immovable properties connected with the school, including those listed in the plaint schedule M.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that on or about 19th March, 1917, seven persons signed a memorandum of Association and registered themselves as members of the Society under Act XXI of 1860. Defendant says that all these persons were the trustees

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondents admitted all properties covered by deed in written statement; new argument not pleaded below rejected.

holdings.text: Defendants 1 to 11 were not validly appointed trustees under the trust deed dated 15-9-1909 in respect of the trust properties mentioned in the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Are defendants 2 to 11 duly appointed trustees under the trust deed dated 15-9-1909 ? The Trial Court answered this question in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No power to transfer to society; illegal and void act; lower courts erred relying on para 6.

holdings.text: Defendants 1 to 11 are trustees de son tort in respect of the trust properties and liable to render accounts for their period of management and be removed.

anchor.surface_text: Their possession and management of these properties must therefore be held to be only in the character of trustee de son tort. They are liable therefore to account for their entire period of management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid appointment but managed properties; wrongful trustees liable as de son tort.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether there was misapplication of funds for 1925 litigation or admission of non-Bohra students was breach of trust.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General challenged the correctness of the findings of the courts below that these defendants defendants 1 to 11 did not by their misapplication of trust funds to the extent of Rs. 15,596-5-8 and Rs. 900/- commit misappropriation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Removal and accounts ordered anyway regardless of specific breaches; amount already paid.

holdings.text: Defendants 1 to 11 be declared not validly appointed trustees, removed from management, directed to render accounts; new trustees to be appointed by Trial Court; no scheme necessary.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal and order that it be declared that the defendants 1 to 11 are not validly appointed trustees in respect of the trust properties mentioned in the list M annexed to the plaint that the defendants be removed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from invalid appointment; original trustees dead/old; hear community recommendations.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal and order that it be declared that the defendants 1 to 11 are number validly appointed trustees in respect of the trust properties mentioned in the list M annexed to the plaint that the defendants be removed from the management of these properties and they be ordered to render an account of their administration of these properties. N

outcome.relief_summary: Both appeals allowed. Defendants 1-11 declared not validly appointed trustees, removed from management of Burhanpur trust properties (list M), directed to render accounts. Decree against defendants 12-17 set aside as no relief prayed against them. New trustees to be appointed by Trial Court. No scheme framed.

Interest of non-Bohra students safeguarded (per assurance)
